DOC.HEAD: Communists Call For `Human, Democratic Socialism'; Oppose Reunification
Eds: INSERTS one graf after 12th `He said...' to ADD reform group backing German unity; pickup graf 13 pvs `Gysi also...'
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's struggling Communists called for a ``human, democratic socialism'' and stressed their opposition to German reunification as an emergency party congress ended Sunday. The 2,700 Communist delegates scrapped their old party platform and adopted a new one designed to guide the party until its next regular congress in February. The congress ended with a new name for the discredited party, which is trying to maintain a role for itself as elections approach next May. Delegates changed the party's official name from the Socialist Unity Party of Germany to the Socialist Unity Party of Germany-Party of Democratic Socialism. Under pressure from mass pro-democracy protests, the party in the past two months has ousted hard-line leaders, opened the Berlin Wall and other borders, promised free elections and ushered in reforms. In the latest change, Premier Hans Modrow announced that East Germany's new domestic intelligence services will be under direct control of the government. The new agency will replace the hated Ministry for National Security, which was dissolved. The new Communist platform says the party roots lie in the ``Communist and social democratic workers' movement,'' a phrase aimed at disassociating the party from 40 years of Stalinist rule from the top. ``The goal is a new, human, democratic socialism'' in East Germany, the platform said, in an echo of a phrase used by former Czechoslovak Communist leader Alexander Dubcek. Dubcek's attempt to create ``socialism with a human face'' was crushed by East Germany and four other Warsaw Pact nations that invaded his country in 1968. ``It was the first democratic party congress we have staged in decades,'' East German party chief Gregor Gysi told delegates. Gysi, a 41-year-old lawyer who has defended the rights of the opposition, was elected to head the Communists during the first part of the congress Dec. 9-10. The meeting resumed on Saturday. In a keynote speech Sunday, Gysi urged further political, economic and military reforms. He reiterated the Communists' opposition to German reunification, saying East Germany must remain ``a humanistic, socially oriented alternative'' to its capitalist western neighbor, the official news agency ADN reported. He said the existence of two Germanys is ``the guarantee for ensuring peace and stability in Europe,'' according to ADN. However, in Leipzig on Sunday, delegates at the founding party congress of Democratic Awakening, a church-led reform movement, voted 350-35 that the right of German unity should be inscribed in the East German constitution. Gysi also urged the adoption of a new national constitution and creation of a supreme court to defend it. He urged a reduction in the length of army service and ``an immediate freeing of military capacities for the economy.'' Gysi called for discussions with church leaders on a law protecting religion in East Germany. He said the Communists favor protecting ``Jewish religion and culture'' and urged Modrow's government to resume diplomatic relations with Israel. Modrow was quoted by an Israeli newspaper Sunday as saying East Germany is willing to change its policy of denying responsibility for the Nazi Holocaust as a way to establish diplomatic ties with Israel. ``We have approached Israel officially with a request to discuss establishing diplomatic relations,'' Modrow was quoted as saying in an interview in the daily Haaretz. While West Germany has paid billions of dollars in reparations to Holocaust survivors, East Germany traditionally has denied responsibility on the grounds that it did not exist as a state at the time. On Saturday, meanwhile, President Bush said he would be ``very responsive'' to any request from East Germany for emergency wintertime food aid.
